posts.name: Gavriel
posts.cooked: Our team set up a pneumatic system with a double solenoid to divert pressure between two tube pipelines. When we toggle the device the lights on the solenoid switch from side to side but the air flow stays in the same tube. Any ideas on how to solve this?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Can you elaborate on what youre trying to do? Pictures or a diagram/drawing might help.

I suspect you may have misunderstood how this device works, but I can’t say for certain without knowing exactly what you’ve tried.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Fletch1373:

misunderstood how this device works

But you spend your entire FRC life speculating about the unknown - the likely and the bizarre! ( CSA FTA ). OP probably thought the double solenoid chose between supply to A and supply to B when in fact it’s likely supply to A and dump from B. Maybe they’ll tell us our guess was right.

posts.name: Gavriel
posts.cooked:
The air tube coming from our pressure gauge went into the 1 slot of the double solenoid and wouldn’t switch from the 4 to the 2 like it was supposed to when toggled.

Ended up being a problem of not having enough pressure to actuate but is nonetheless fixed. thank you for your reply!

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Not sure what pressure wasn’t enough but if you needed more supply pressure to activate the solenoid then it might have only needed a little more back pressure from the device.  Recently someone was testing without devices attached and solenoid wasn’t switching for them as expected. Glad you got it working.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Pneumatic solenoid valves typically require a “priming” pressure at the input port in order to actuate, so what you found makes sense.  What supply pressure were you giving it?  I generally wouldn’t use anything less than 20psi due to this reason (though the specific pressure required will differ between valve models)
